text: So first, about better economic policy. There's largely two reasons you've got this. So it means that any business which has risk diverse, but just thinking about global conditions, is massively more likely to invest in or do trade with another country because they know that there's no macroeconomic effects that they can't predict that's going to literally send their profits to zero. But additionally, externally, we think that because you have a lot of different countries which often have slightly different structure of their economy, you're less likely to see all of them collapse at once. text: First, why it is broadly good to believe that you are special as a child. The first thing that we would say is that, this idea encourages exploration. I think that when you have this idea you have abilities, that you have potential, you're, one, less afraid to try things for fear of failure. And, two, you are more motivated to find something that you are particularly good at, to find something that lets you tap into that specialness, that lets you tap into that sense of destiny. We think it's just good, in a practical sense, that is to say it gives children a leg up. They get a variety of experiences that they can parlay things later in life. But we also think it gives them early experience in discovering some identity, some sense of who they are. Because it's important to try things and not like those things. It's important to try on different roles as a child and reject some of those roles, and learn how to grow and change as a person with different things that you do over time. That's how children gain that confidence to explore who they are, and that includes interpersonal confidence. I didn't play with other children at recess until third grade because I was afraid of them. I think that the idea that children bring something special, that they are valuable in and of themselves, makes them more confident to engage with other children as well. It makes them more able to engage in those social situations and find out who they are.
label: constructive1

text: The second thing I would claim is that, it encourages them to be devoted to particular things. Because when you have this idea of potential, you want to fulfill that potential, so you want to spend time practicing whatever it is that you care about. We think that's good, in that it teaches you certain skills. It teaches you the value of perseverance. It teaches you hard work. We also think it is good, in that in the absence of you being intrinsically motivated, we think your parents might be likely to push you in ways that might not be desirable. Because your parents still want you to succeed and be exceptional. But we think a better, on the comparative, way to motivate that is by inculcating in the children some sense that their work will pay off because there is something special about them, rather than having to push them in ways that might strain that relationship.
label: constructive2

text: The third claim that I'd make about why it's good to believe you're special as a child, is that it sets a certain moral standard. It sets an expectation of how you will act in the world. And the idea being that specialness is holistic, that is to say, you are special as an agent, as a person. And there is something about that specialness which means that you have some responsibility to act in such a way that is dignified and that befits your status. So, why do I think all of this really matters from the position of child? Because we think that people can and do develop more sophisticated moral systems later. The important thing as a child is that they have confidence, that they have the ability to learn basic social skills and to explore basic things about their identity, and to explore basic things about who they are. That's what allows them to develop more sophisticated moral systems later. Yeah.

I would note two additional implications of this arguments about what the world says. The first, is that some children will think they're special anyway because the world's going to tell them that because of their identity characteristics. Note, that when their world from a very young age is competitive, when they're world from very young age is putting them into contact with other people who might be better at certain things, we think the messages at home serve a counterbalancing effect. That is to say, they will think that they are special in some senses and not in others because the world is telling them one thing and they're learning another thing at home. So, the impact of internalizing this message fully is mitigated to some extent.
